image.altText: A close up of Taylor Swift at an event, where her wavy hair is partly pulled back and she wears several gold necklaces.

items.synopsis: This morning's news as it happens.

title.children: Stars arrive on the pink carpet ahead of the VMAs. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yes, that's iconic 90s boy band NSYNC, handing Taylor Swift the first award of the night at the VMAs. Swift, who is the most-nominated artist tonight with 11 nominations, just won Best Pop video for her hit Anti-Hero off the album Midnights. "I had your dolls!" she said on stage to band members like Lance Bass and Justin Timberlake. "You are pop personified. So to receive this from your golden pop hands, it's too much." Meanwhile, enjoy Swift fangirling with Ice Spice when NSYNC appeared on stage.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Taylor Swift wins Best Pop award from NSYNC at VMAs

children.content: Yes, that's iconic 90s boy band NSYNC, handing Taylor Swift the first award of the night at the VMAs.

props.alt: Taylor on stage with the boy band.

children.content: (Reuters: Brendan Mcdermid)
Swift, who is the most-nominated artist tonight with 11 nominations, just won Best Pop video for her hit Anti-Hero off the album Midnights.
"I had your dolls!" she said on stage to band members like Lance Bass and Justin Timberlake.
"You are pop personified. So to receive this from your golden pop hands, it's too much."
Meanwhile, enjoy Swift fangirling with Ice Spice when NSYNC appeared on stage.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Transport Workers Union national secretary Michael Kaine has called for Richard Goyder and the Qantas board to go following the High Court decision over the sacking of 1,700 workers. "These workers have been through hell and back, and today, there are smiles on their faces, smiles on their faces because it's been three years of hell for their families and now, justice has prevailed," he said. "Richard Goyder and the board have been compliant in this illegal sacking of 1,700 workers. "On numerous occasions, Richard Goyder backed in Alan Joyce in relation to this very decision." Qantas has just released a statement responding to the High Court decision. "Qantas acknowledges and accepts the High Court’s decision to uphold two prior rulings by the Federal Court regarding the legality of outsourcing the remainder of the airline’s ground handling function in 2020," it reads. "As we have said from the beginning, we deeply regret the personal impact the outsourcing decision had on all those affected and we sincerely apologise for that."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas decision a 'victory for workers', says TWU, as it calls for Goyder to go

props.alt: A man in a blue suit surrounded by people.

children.content: (ABC News)
Transport Workers Union national secretary Michael Kaine has called for Richard Goyder and the Qantas board to go following the High Court decision over the sacking of 1,700 workers.

"These workers have been through hell and back, and today, there are smiles on their faces, smiles on their faces because it's been three years of hell for their families and now, justice has prevailed," he said.
"Richard Goyder and the board have been compliant in this illegal sacking of 1,700 workers.
"On numerous occasions, Richard Goyder backed in Alan Joyce in relation to this very decision."
Qantas has just released a statement responding to the High Court decision.

"Qantas acknowledges and accepts the High Court’s decision to uphold two prior rulings by the Federal Court regarding the legality of outsourcing the remainder of the airline’s ground handling function in 2020," it reads.
"As we have said from the beginning, we deeply regret the personal impact the outsourcing decision had on all those affected and we sincerely apologise for that."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Recently retired legend Jack Riewoldt will play a key role in the Tasmanian AFL club's formation. Riewoldt headlines a powerful group of local and expat Tasmanians on the inaugural board, including Brisbane Lions premiership hero Alastair Lynch, high-powered talent manager James Henderson and Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre chairman Graeme Gardner. The eight-person board will be unveiled in Launceston this afternoon, with Richmond great Riewoldt to be confirmed as the club's official culture lead, ahead of a tipped 2028 start date.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Riewoldt, Lynch to headline Tasmanian AFL team

featuredLink.title: Tiger great Riewoldt and ex-Lion Lynch among newly announced Tasmanian AFL leadership team

children.content: Recently retired legend Jack Riewoldt will play a key role in the Tasmanian AFL club's formation.

Riewoldt headlines a powerful group of local and expat Tasmanians on the inaugural board, including Brisbane Lions premiership hero Alastair Lynch, high-powered talent manager James Henderson and Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre chairman Graeme Gardner.
The eight-person board will be unveiled in Launceston this afternoon, with Richmond great Riewoldt to
be confirmed as the club's official culture lead, ahead of a tipped 2028 start date.

items.synopsis: Apple's iPhone announcement and higher oil prices send Wall Street lower, and Qantas loses its High Court appeal over the sacking of 1,700 workers during the pandemic. Follow updates in our live blog.

title.children: Qantas loses High Court appeal over mass sacking, Wall Street slides on oil prices, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has just released a statement in response to this morning's High Court ruling. Here it is in full: "Qantas acknowledges and accepts the High Court's decision to uphold two prior rulings by the Federal Court regarding the legality of outsourcing the remainder of the airline's ground handling function in 2020. "The Federal Court originally found that while there were valid and lawful commercial reasons for the outsourcing, it could not rule out that Qantas also had an unlawful reason – namely, avoiding future industrial action. The High Court has now effectively upheld this interpretation. "The decision to outsource the remainder of the airline's ground handling function was made in August 2020, when borders were closed, lockdowns were in place and no COVID vaccine existed. The likelihood of a years' long crisis led Qantas to restructure its business to improve its ability to survive and ultimately recover. "As we have said from the beginning, we deeply regret the personal impact the outsourcing decision had on all those affected and we sincerely apologise for that. "A prior decision by the Federal Court has ruled out reinstatement of workers but it will now consider penalties for the breach and compensation for relevant employees, which will factor in redundancy payments already made by Qantas."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas releases statement on High Court verdict

children.content: Qantas has just released a statement in response to this morning's High Court ruling. Here it is in full:

"Qantas acknowledges and accepts the High Court's decision to uphold two prior rulings by the Federal Court regarding the legality of outsourcing the remainder of the airline's ground handling function in 2020.

"The Federal Court originally found that while there were valid and lawful commercial reasons for the outsourcing, it could not rule out that Qantas also had an unlawful reason – namely, avoiding future industrial action. The High Court has now effectively upheld this interpretation.

"The decision to outsource the remainder of the airline's ground handling function was made in August 2020, when borders were closed, lockdowns were in place and no COVID vaccine existed. The likelihood of a years' long crisis led Qantas to restructure its business to improve its ability to survive and ultimately recover.
"As we have said from the beginning,
we deeply regret the personal impact the outsourcing decision had on all those affected and we sincerely apologise for that.
"A prior decision by the Federal Court has ruled out reinstatement of workers but
it will now consider penalties for the breach and compensation for relevant employees,
which will factor in redundancy payments already made by Qantas."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The TWU is speaking now in Canberra: "There are serious consequences that should flow from this. Richard Goyder and the board should go. Richard Goyder and the board have been complicit in this illegal sacking of 1,700 workers. "On numerous occasions, Richard Goyder backed in Alan Joyce in relation to this very decision. "And we know that Richard Goyder was complicit of it at all. "This has been a spiteful dictatorship and the board has been right behind Alan Joyce. "But their last act before they walk out the door should be to rip away from Alan Joyce, the obscene bonuses that he has taken as these families suffer. "The bonuses have to go, the board has to go. "And a message for the new CEO - Vanessa Hudson - you owe these workers and their families a deep and sincere apology. "These workers have been put through hell. Their families have been put through hell. "Their lives have been dislocated. Some of them forever."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas owes workers 'a deep and sincere apology' for illegally sacking them in 2020, TWU says

children.content: The TWU is speaking now in Canberra:
"There are serious consequences that should flow from this. Richard Goyder and the board should go. Richard Goyder and the board have been complicit in this illegal sacking of 1,700 workers.
"On numerous occasions, Richard Goyder backed in Alan Joyce in relation to this very decision.
"And we know that Richard Goyder was complicit of it at all.
"This has been a spiteful dictatorship and the board has been right behind Alan Joyce.
"But their last act before they walk out the door should be to rip away from Alan Joyce, the obscene bonuses that he has taken as these families suffer.
"The bonuses have to go, the board has to go.
"And a message for the new CEO - Vanessa Hudson -
you owe these workers and their families a deep and sincere apology.
"These workers have been put through hell. Their families have been put through hell.
"Their lives have been dislocated. Some of them forever."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, Australian shares have opened lower, following Wall Street's losses. The ASX 200 is down -0.5% to 7173 points as at 10:15am AEST. The broader All Ordinaries is down -0.5% to 7365 points. We're seeing mixed performances from the sectors; with materials and energy dragging and utilities and financials up. The top movers are: Link Administration +6% Imugene Limited +5% Megaport Limited +3.4% Ingenia Communities Group +3.2% Champion Iron +2.4% The bottom movers are: Viva Energy -7% Brainchip Holdings -6.8% Beach Energy -3% Lendlease Group -3% Lake Resources -2.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower

children.content: As expected, Australian shares have opened lower, following Wall Street's losses.
The ASX 200 is down -0.5% to 7173 points as at 10:15am AEST.
The broader All Ordinaries is down -0.5% to 7365 points.
We're seeing mixed performances from the sectors; with materials and energy dragging and utilities and financials up.
The top movers are:
Link Administration +6%
Imugene Limited +5%
Megaport Limited +3.4%
Ingenia Communities Group +3.2%
Champion Iron +2.4%
The bottom movers are:
Viva Energy -7%
Brainchip Holdings -6.8%
Beach Energy -3%
Lendlease Group -3%
Lake Resources -2.8%
